summary: This is a First Amended Complaint filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida by an anonymous plaintiff against Jeffrey Epstein and Sarah Kellen. The complaint alleges a pattern of sexual abuse and exploitation of the plaintiff when she was a minor, detailing specific incidents at Epstein's Palm Beach residence in 2004. It references Epstein's 2008 guilty plea in Florida state court and his non-prosecution agreement with the federal government. This document is a portion of a First Amended Complaint filed in a civil lawsuit (Case No. 08-CV-80811) against Jeffrey Epstein. It details multiple counts of alleged sexual abuse against a minor plaintiff, invoking rights under 18 USC §2255 based on Epstein's non-prosecution agreement with the federal government. The text describes specific abusive incidents in August, September, and October of an unspecified year. This document is a section of a First Amended Complaint in a civil lawsuit (Case No. 08-CV-80811) against Jeffrey Epstein. It details multiple counts (X through XIV) alleging sexual abuse of a minor plaintiff on specific dates in October, November, and December, and invokes rights under 18 USC § 2255 based on Epstein's non-prosecution agreement with the federal government. This document is pages 44-57 of a First Amended Complaint filed in a civil lawsuit (Case No. 08-CV-80811) against Jeffrey Epstein. It details multiple counts (XV through XX) alleging sexual abuse of a minor plaintiff in January, February, and March of an unspecified year, invoking rights under 18 USC §2255 based on Epstein's non-prosecution agreement with the federal government. This document is a segment of a First Amended Complaint in a civil lawsuit (Case No. 08-CV-80811) against Jeffrey Epstein. It details multiple counts of alleged sexual abuse against a minor plaintiff, referencing a specific agreement from Epstein's criminal plea that granted victims rights under 18 U.S.C. § 2255. The text describes several alleged incidents of abuse in April, May, and June of an unspecified year, and outlines the plaintiff's claims for damages. This document is a segment of a First Amended Complaint filed in civil case 08-CV-80811 against Jeffrey Epstein. It details multiple counts (XXVI through XXX) brought by a plaintiff, Jane Doe #1, under 18 USC §2255, alleging specific sexual abuse incidents in June, July, and August of 2003. The complaint cites Epstein's non-prosecution agreement with the federal government as establishing his liability. This document is pages 86-91 of a First Amended Complaint filed in a civil lawsuit against Jeffrey Epstein and Sarah Kellen. It contains specific counts alleging sexual battery by Epstein and conspiracy to commit tortious assault by Kellen, detailing their roles in facilitating abuse against a minor plaintiff. The document concludes with a certificate of service and a list of attorneys.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The accused perpetrator of sexual offenses against the minor plaintiff, as detailed in multiple counts of the civil complaint. The document states he entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the federal government.

persons.name: Sarah Kellen
persons.context: Named as a defendant and described as Epstein's employee/assistant who allegedly conspired with him, facilitated sexual assaults, arranged meetings, delivered cash, and took nude photographs of the plaintiff.

persons.name: Jane Doe #1
persons.context: The anonymous plaintiff bringing the civil action against Jeffrey Epstein, alleging she was a minor victim of sexual abuse on multiple occasions in 2003.

persons.name: Robert Critton
persons.context: Listed as counsel for the plaintiff(s) from the law firm Burman Critton Luttier & Coleman LLP.

persons.name: Jack A. Goldberger
persons.context: Listed as counsel for the plaintiff(s) from the law firm Atterbury, Goldberger & Weiss, P.A.

persons.name: Bruce E. Reinhart
persons.context: Listed as counsel for the plaintiff(s) from Bruce E. Reinhart, P.A.

connections.description: Both are named as defendants in the same civil lawsuit filed by the anonymous plaintiff.
Epstein is alleged to have sexually abused the plaintiff when she was a minor on multiple occasions in 2003, paying her over $200 per encounter.
Kellen is described as Epstein's employee/assistant who aided, assisted, and/or abetted him in his organized scheme to sexually assault and coerce the plaintiff.
The complaint alleges Epstein and Kellen reached an agreement for the purpose of allowing Epstein to commit illegal sexual acts upon the plaintiff.

events.title: First alleged abuse incident
events.description: The plaintiff, then 15, was first brought to Epstein's mansion by a female friend. She observed a sexual act performed on Epstein by the friend and was paid $300.

events.title: Second alleged abuse incident
events.description: Approximately one week after the first incident, Epstein called the plaintiff back to his residence, directed her to undress partially, gave her a massage, and then masturbated in her presence, paying her $300.

events.title: Third alleged abuse incident
events.description: The plaintiff returned to Epstein's residence at his request. He directed her to undress to her underwear, gave her a massage, and masturbated in her presence, paying over $200.

events.title: Fourth alleged abuse incident
events.description: The plaintiff returned to Epstein's residence a second time in July. He directed her to fully undress, fondled her breasts and buttocks during a massage, and masturbated in her presence, paying over $200.

events.title: Epstein's guilty plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered guilty pleas in the Fifteenth Judicial Circuit in Palm Beach County, Florida, to state crimes involving solicitation and procurement of minors for prostitution.

events.title: Filing of Civil Lawsuit
events.description: The plaintiff files a First Amended Complaint (Case No. 08-CV-80811) against Jeffrey Epstein, alleging sexual abuse while she was a minor.

events.title: Epstein's Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Reference to a prior agreement between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Government, where in exchange for not being prosecuted for federal offenses, Epstein agreed to grant victims rights under 18 USC §2255 as if he had been convicted.

events.title: First August Abuse Incident
events.description: The plaintiff, then a minor, returned to Epstein's residence at his request, was directed to undress and give a massage, was fondled, and Epstein masturbated in her presence. She was paid over $200.

events.title: Second August Abuse Incident
events.description: A second incident in August with identical details: the minor plaintiff was fondled during a massage and Epstein masturbated in her presence, paying over $200.

events.title: First September Abuse Incident
events.description: The plaintiff returned to Epstein's residence, was directed to undress and give a massage, was fondled, and Epstein masturbated in her presence. She was paid over $200.

events.title: Second September Abuse Incident

events.title: Criminal Plea and Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a plea agreement with the Federal Government, avoiding prosecution for federal offenses. The agreement included a provision granting victims rights under 18 USC §2255 as if Epstein had been convicted.

events.title: Epstein's Criminal Plea Agreement
events.description: As a condition of his criminal plea, Jeffrey Epstein entered into an agreement with the Federal Government. The agreement stipulated that any minor victim of an offense enumerated in 18 U.S.C. § 2255 would have the same rights to proceed under that statute as if Epstein had been federally tried and convicted. The U.S. was to provide Epstein's attorneys with a list of individuals it was prepared to name as victims in an indictment.

events.title: First Alleged Abuse Incident in April
events.description: The plaintiff returned to Jeffrey Epstein's residence at his request. Epstein directed her to fully undress and provide a massage, fondled her breasts and buttocks, and then masturbated in her presence. He paid her in excess of $200.

events.description: The plaintiff returned to Epstein's residence a second time in April. The same pattern of events occurred: she was directed to undress and give a massage, was fondled, and Epstein masturbated in her presence. He paid over $200.

events.title: Filing of First Amended Complaint

events.title: Period of Alleged Sexual Battery

locations: Residence of Jeffrey Epstein (in Palm Beach County, Florida)
keyFacts: The plaintiff alleges Jeffrey Epstein operated a scheme to gain access to and sexually exploit economically disadvantaged minor girls, paying them money.
The complaint details four specific incidents of alleged sexual abuse against the plaintiff at Epstein's Palm Beach mansion in 2004, when she was 15 years old.
The document states Epstein kept a written log of each instance he engaged in illegal acts with the minor plaintiff and others.
The lawsuit is filed under a fictitious name to protect the plaintiff's identity due to the nature of the allegations.

The complaint references Epstein's 2008 guilty plea in Florida state court and a related non-prosecution agreement with the federal government that granted victims certain rights to sue under 18 U.S.C. § 2255.
The civil complaint is based on a provision in Jeffrey Epstein's non-prosecution agreement that grants alleged victims the right to sue under 18 USC §2255 as if he had been federally convicted.

The document alleges a pattern of abuse where the minor plaintiff was summoned to Epstein's residence on multiple occasions in August, September, and October, paid for 'massages,' fondled, and subjected to him masturbating in her presence.
The plaintiff's name is redacted throughout the document, indicated by placeholders like 'C.M.A' and blank spaces, consistent with protective orders.
The lawsuit seeks compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorney's fees, and costs for physical, emotional, and financial injuries described as permanent.
Each count of abuse follows an identical legal structure, citing the non-prosecution agreement and detailing the specific incident and resulting harms.

The complaint alleges a repeated, specific pattern of abuse: the minor plaintiff was summoned to Epstein's residence, directed to undress and give a massage, fondled, and Epstein would masturbate in her presence, paying over $200 each time.

The plaintiff's cause of action is based on 18 USC § 2255, invoking a provision from Epstein's non-prosecution agreement with the federal government that grants victims the same rights as if he had been convicted at trial.
The document states that as part of his plea deal, Epstein agreed the government would provide his attorneys with a list of individuals it was prepared to name as victims in an indictment.
The plaintiff claims extensive and permanent damages including physical injury, psychological trauma, loss of income, and loss of capacity to enjoy life.
The plaintiff's name is consistently redacted in the provided text, indicated by blank spaces or underscores where the name would be.

The plaintiff alleges at least six specific incidents of sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein in January, February, and March of an unspecified year, each following a similar pattern of a paid massage leading to fondling and masturbation.
Each encounter is alleged to have involved payment 'in excess of $200' by Epstein to the minor plaintiff.
The lawsuit invokes 18 USC §2255, citing a provision in Epstein's non-prosecution agreement that grants victims the same rights as if he had been federally tried and convicted.
The complaint states that as part of his plea deal, the U.S. government agreed to provide Epstein's attorneys with a list of individuals it was prepared to name as victims in an indictment.
The plaintiff claims extensive and permanent damages including physical injury, emotional distress, psychological trauma, loss of income, and medical expenses.

The document reveals a key provision of Jeffrey Epstein's non-prosecution agreement: it granted victims of his enumerated offenses the same rights to sue under 18 U.S.C. § 2255 as if he had been federally convicted.
The U.S. government was obligated to provide Epstein's attorneys with a list of individuals it was prepared to name as victims in a federal indictment.
The civil complaint details a pattern of alleged abuse across multiple months (April, May, June) where the minor plaintiff was paid over $200 per encounter for massages that escalated to sexual acts.
The plaintiff's name is redacted throughout the document, indicated by underscores or blank spaces, consistent with protective orders.
The lawsuit seeks compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorney's fees, and costs, citing permanent physical and psychological injuries to the plaintiff.

The plaintiff, Jane Doe #1, alleges at least six specific incidents of sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein in June, July, and August of 2003, each following a similar pattern and ending with a payment of over $200.

The civil cause of action is brought under 18 USC §2255, citing a non-prosecution agreement between Epstein and the federal government that treats him as if convicted for the purpose of victim lawsuits.
The complaint alleges the agreement requires the U.S. government to provide Epstein's attorneys with a list of individuals it was prepared to name as victims in an indictment.
The plaintiff claims extensive and permanent damages including physical injury, emotional distress, psychological trauma, loss of income, and loss of capacity to enjoy life.
The document is a First Amended Complaint filed on February 9, 2009, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida (Case No.: 08-CV-80811).
The plaintiff alleges Jeffrey Epstein engaged in dozens of illegal sexual acts against her over a period from late May/early June to August, constituting sexual battery.
Sarah Kellen is accused of conspiring with Epstein, facilitating the abuse by arranging meetings, escorting the plaintiff, delivering cash, and taking nude photographs for Epstein.
The plaintiff claims severe and permanent injuries including psychological trauma, loss of income, and medical expenses as a result of the defendants' actions.
The document is a formal court filing (First Amended Complaint) in Case No. 08-CV-80811, electronically filed on February 9, 2009.
The plaintiff's name is redacted throughout the provided text, indicated by blank spaces or placeholders like 'Plaintiff, '.
